timeline.bodyText:
I think this test case can be simplified a bit, depending on what you want to check:
A) to check only the deserialization, prepare the expected object and use assertIsEqualToComparingFieldByFieldRecursively to make sure it's equal to the object deserialized from JSON
B) in case you want to check also serialization, you can deserialize and again serialize the JSON and compare it as a String with the original JSON String. This way you check also formatting (not sure how much relevant it is in this case).
timeline.author: rsynek

replies.bodyText:
I've been looking at the signature of the suggested alternative A) method, see below, but honestly I don't like it and don't see it as a huge simplification. The package "internal" see org.assertj.core.internal.Objects dosen't look inspiring to use too. O the other hand this format is never used in all kogito-runtimes, kogito-apps or even OptaPlanner.
I think current test is ok, what we are testing is a Deserializer, so it's intended to basically take a json  and return a pojo, and this is exactly what the test does.
I'll will go with this format.
void assertIsEqualToComparingFieldByFieldRecursively(AssertionInfo info,
Object actual,
Object other,
Map<String,Comparator<?>> comparatorByPropertyOrField,
TypeComparators comparatorByType)
